Note: If the financial institution information we have on file is no longer active, you may need to cancel your Pre-Authorized Debit. Visit our Contact Us(https://protege-secure-2.csnpe-nslsc.canada.ca/eng/ContactUs.aspx) page for options on how to connect with us. Our agents are available to assist you Monday to Friday, from 8:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m., your local time.

title: What do I submit if I do not have any income?
content:
If you do not have any income or have declared $0 gross income, we need a personal statement from you. A personal statement is a written letter explaining how you are living without an income.
 
For example, if you are receiving support from your parent(s), please state that in your letter. Other examples are:
Receiving support from other family members and/or from a friend     
Using personal savings
 
Also, please include the following information:
First and last name
Social Insurance Number (SIN) or loan number
Specify the month for which you indicated that your gross monthly income was $0.

title: What is a GCKey?
content: GCKey is an electronic credential that allows you to securely access the Government of Canada's online services. It includes a username and password that you choose. It is important that you remember your credential to avoid being locked out of your account in the future.

title: What is a Government Sign-In by Verified.Me?
content:
Government Sign-In by Verified.Me (Sign-In Partner) is a secure way to sign into your online account using information you already have.
 
Sign-In Partners are groups like banks and credit unions that partner with Verified.Me technologies to enable their customers to use their online credentials, such as card numbers or usernames and passwords, to access Government of Canada services. It is important that you remember your credentials to avoid being locked out of your account in the future.

title: What is floating and fixed interest rate?
content:
A floating interest rate is a rate of interest that varies over time with the Prime Rate. If you choose a floating interest rate, the interest you are charged will increase and decrease along with the Prime Rate. 
 
A fixed interest rate is a stable rate of interest. If you choose a fixed rate, you will be charged the same interest rate throughout your repayment period.
Once you choose a fixed interest rate, you cannot return to a floating interest rate.
 
Interest is calculated either at a fixed interest rate of Prime Rate + 2.0%* or at a floating interest rate equal to the Prime Rate for Canada Student Loans and Canada-New Brunswick Integrated Student Loans.
 
For information on Canada Student Loan and Canada Integrated Student Loans’ interest rates, please check the FAQ page(https://www.csnpe-nslsc.canada.ca/en/frequently-asked-questions) on the NSLSC.ca.

title: What is my MSFAA number?
content: Your 10-digit MSFAA number is issued by your Province/Territory and is required to complete the online registration. To find your MSFAA number, we recommend checking the communications you have received from your Province/Territory regarding your student financial assistance.

title: What is my OSAP Access Number (OAN)?
content:
The OSAP Access Number (OAN) is a nine-digit number that is assigned to each student who has applied for funding by the province of Ontario.
 
If you’re not sure if you have an OAN or if you forgot your OAN, go to Ontario.ca/OSAP(https://www.ontario.ca/page/osap-ontario-student-assistance-program), select “Log in” and then select “Forgot OAN” or password” located on the left hand side of the main log in screen for further assistance.

title: What is my payout balance?
content:
The amount showing on your Dashboard is the total amount to be repaid, including principal and interest. 
 
If you are not making a payment today, take the amount owing and add the daily interest up until the date you plan to pay out your loan. 
 
The daily interest can be found through the Loan Details page. From your Dashboard, click on “Loan Type and Number” under “Funding Summary”.
 
Note to Agents: If customer insist – use response below.
 
I can confirm whether you have the correct amount. Can you please give me the amount showing on your Dashboard?

title: What is Repayment Assistance Plan (RAP)?
content:
The Repayment Assistance Plan (RAP)(https://www.canada.ca/en/services/benefits/education/student-aid/grants-loans/repay/assistance/rap.html) is a loan repayment option that helps students make their scheduled loan payments and keep their loan in good standing. RAP can prevent students experiencing financial difficulties from negatively affecting their credit rating.
 
If you are experiencing financial difficulties and are unable to make your regularly scheduled monthly student loan payments, you can apply for RAP. Depending on your situation, RAP can reduce or even eliminate your monthly payments while keeping your loan in good standing without negatively affecting your credit.
 
Applying for RAP
You can apply for the Repayment Assistance Plan (RAP)(https://www.csnpe-nslsc.canada.ca/en/repaying-your-loan) online through your secure NSLSC account.(https://protege-secure.csnpe-nslsc.canada.ca/en/public/sign-in-method)
 
Under “My Account” select “Repayment Assistance Plan” and click on “Apply On-Line Now”.  
 
Your application will be processed within 3 business days if all information is complete and accurate. Keep an eye on your inbox! We will contact you if additional information is required.

title: What is the difference between a GCKey and a Sign-In Partner?
content: Government Sign-In by Verified.Me offers a convenient way to access your account by signing in with your online banking credential while GCKey allows you to create your own username and password. In both cases, it is important that you remember your credentials to avoid being locked out of your account in the future.

title: What is the interest rate on my student loan?
content:
You can find your student loan interest rate and daily interest charge through the Loan Details page. 
 
From your Dashboard, click on “Loan Type and Number” under the “Funding Summary” to see your interest rate.

title: What is the term on my student loan?
content: You can find out the term of your student loan by logging in to your secure NSLSC account(https://protege-secure.csnpe-nslsc.canada.ca/en/public/sign-in-method).Click on “Loan Type and Number” under the “Funding Summary” heading on your account Dashboard to see your loan details

title: What is the website to register for my student loans?
content: To register your NSLSC account, go to https://www.csnpe-nslsc.canada.ca/. Click on the “Register” button on the Homepage to begin.

title: What’s the remaining term on my loan?
content:
You can find the remaining term of your student loan by logging in to your secure NSLSC account.(https://protege-secure.csnpe-nslsc.canada.ca/en/public/sign-in-method)
 
Click on “Loan Type and Number” under the “Funding Summary” heading on your account Dashboard to see your loan details.

title: When does my loan enter repayment?
content:
From the last day of the month in which you finished your studies, you have a six-month non-repayment (grace) period before your loan enters repayment. For example, if you start your last year of studies in September and finish in April, your first payment will be due six months later in November.
 
You can check the status and balance of your loan anytime by logging in to your secure NSLSC account(https://protege-secure.csnpe-nslsc.canada.ca/en/public/sign-in-method). Details of your loan repayment can be found in your secure inbox about a month before your repayment period starts. We will also send you an email when these details become available.

title: When will I receive my money?
content:
Your student grant or loan will be deposited directly into the bank account you provided on your secure NSLSC account and/or forwarded to your school to pay your tuition on or after the first day of classes.
 
You can track the status of your funds in real-time using the Funding Tracker found on your account dashboard. It will keep you updated on the status of your funds throughout the disbursement process.
 
Log in to your NSLSC account to view your Dashboard.

title: Where can I find my repayment details?
content:
You can find your repayment details in the Repayment Notice sent to your NSLSC account secure inbox. Look for a notification with the subject line “Your Payments will Begin Soon”.
 
Log in to your account(https://protege-secure.csnpe-nslsc.canada.ca/en/public/sign-in-method) to view your secure inbox.

title: Where can I get my income tax receipt?
content:
You can access your interest paid receipts by logging in to your secure NSLSC account.(https://protege-secure.csnpe-nslsc.canada.ca/en/public/sign-in-method)
 
From your Dashboard, select “My Inbox” to access your income tax receipts.
 
Your tax receipt and annual statement are typically available mid-January, while we will issue your T4A by the end of February.

title: Where can I mail in my proof of income? I can’t upload online as I’m locked out and my account cannot be unlocked.
content:
You can mail in your proof of income to:
 
NSLSC
P.O. Box 4030, Mississauga
ON, L5A 4M4
 
For proof of income, we go by the pay date and not by pay period. Please make sure your pay stubs are dated for <<Month>> <<Year>>. Don’t forget to include your name and Social Insurance Number (SIN) or loan account number on each document.

title: Where can I submit my CIFS form?
content: If you’re a full-time student, you can submit a Continuation of Interest-Free Status (CIFS) Application online(https://osap.gov.on.ca/OSAPSecurityWeb/public/login.xhtml?lang=en) or complete and mail the form(https://osap.gov.on.ca/prdosapconsum/groups/forms/documents/forms/tcont003388.pdf). This will keep your OSAP loans interest-free.

title: Where can I view my statement of account?
content:
You can view your statement of account by logging in(https://protege-secure.csnpe-nslsc.canada.ca/en/public/sign-in-method) to your secure NSLSC account.
 
Once you are logged in:
 
Click the “Loan Type and Number” under the “Funding Summary” heading on your account Dashboard to see your loan details
Click on “View Loan Statement”

title: Why did my funding go to my school?
content:
Your school requested that we forward some or all of your funding to them to pay for your academic fees (e.g. tuition).
 
You can check your account Dashboard for a breakdown of where and how much of your funding was sent.
 
If you have any questions about why your funding went directly to your school, check with your school's student financial assistance office.

title: Why did my RAP application expire?
content:
Your Repayment Assistance Plan (RAP) application expired because it was missing information and the missing information was not received within 45 days. 
 
Log in to your secure NSLSC account(https://protege-secure.csnpe-nslsc.canada.ca/en/public/sign-in-method) to submit a new application.

title: Why do I need to pay outstanding interest to process my RAP application? Loan in arrears for 6+ months
content:
The Repayment Assistance Plan (RAP) can only be used for 6 months at a time. This includes backdating for any missed payments within the last 6 months of your application date. Since you are <<Insert Number of Months in Arrears>>, we can only backdate your RAP application until <<Insert Date>>. The remaining outstanding interest is required to process your application.
 
If you are not able to make a payment, you can add up to 3 months of the outstanding interest to your student loan(s) balance. This is a one-time option throughout the lifetime of your loan. If you choose this option, you will need to sign and return a consolidation form, confirming that you authorize us to add the outstanding interest towards your loan balance.

title: Why do the dates on the Funding Tracker keep changing?
content:
If there is an unresolved issue with the funding (such as missing information), then you may notice the estimated received date changing while the issue is being resolved. If an action is required from you to resolve an issue, we will notify you.
 
Please check your Dashboard on your secure NSLSC account(https://protege-secure.csnpe-nslsc.canada.ca/en/public/sign-in-method) to confirm if there are any actions you need to take before that can happen.

title: Why have I received a repayment notification? I am still in school.
content:
You have received a repayment notification because we did not receive proof of your ongoing studies.
 
To keep your loan in non-repayment status and prevent interest from accruing on your student loan, you must confirm your enrolment at the beginning of every year of study, even if you are not seeking additional financial assistance.
 
You can submit a request for confirmation of enrolment through your secure NSLSC account(https://protege-secure.csnpe-nslsc.canada.ca/en/public/sign-in-method). Select “Confirmation of Enrolment” under the “Manage a Loan” tab on the Dashboard.

title: Why is my loan in arrears?
content:
Your loan is in arrears because you are overdue on one or more student loan payments. To bring your student loan back into good standing, you need to pay the outstanding balance.
 
To check your outstanding balance, log in to your secure NSLSC account(https://protege-secure.csnpe-nslsc.canada.ca/en/public/sign-in-method). The balance is displayed on your Dashboard.
 
Additional Information the Agent can provide:
 
The NSLSC does offer loan repayment options to help make your loan payments more affordable and keep your loan in good standing.
 
Learn more about your Loan Repayment Options(https://www.csnpe-nslsc.canada.ca/en/repaying-your-loan).
 
There are several payment options available to you to pay your overdue balance:
 
NSLSC Account: Log in to your account(https://protege-secure.csnpe-nslsc.canada.ca/en/public/sign-in-method) and select “Make a Payment” from the “My Account” drop down menu.
 
Online Banking: Add NSLSC as a Payee using your loan number as the bill number and pay the outstanding balance. 
 
Cheque, Money Order or Bank Draft: Make the payment method payable to the NSLSC, include your loan number in the "memo" or "note" section and mail it to the NSLSC at the address below:
 
NSLSC
P.O. Box 4030, Mississauga
Ontario, L5A 4M4
 
To avoid missing payments in the future, we recommend setting up Pre-Authorized Debit (PAD) to automate your payments to ensure they are made in full and on time each month. Log in to your secure NSLSC account(https://protege-secure.csnpe-nslsc.canada.ca/en/public/sign-in-method) and select “Activate Pre-Authorized Debit” from the “My Account” drop down menu

title: Why is my RAP application taking so long to be processed?
content: We are currently working through a high volume of applications, so it might take us a little bit longer than usual to get back to you. We will send you an email when your application has been processed. We will ensure you are not negatively impacted by these technical difficulties.

title: Why was application refused? (High Income)
content:
Your Repayment Assistance Plan (RAP) application was refused because your income was above the limit. 
 
If there has been, or you anticipate there will be, a decrease in your income, you may re-apply.
 
There are also other loan repayment options available to you. You can lower your monthly payments to better suit your budget by extending the term of your student loan repayment. 
 
You can customize the terms of your loan(s) online by selecting “Customize My Payment Terms” from the “My Account” drop-down menu. You can then change your payment term or amount.
 
For a step-by-step guide to customizing your payment terms, please visit the Additional Resources (https://www.csnpe-nslsc.canada.ca/en/additional-resources) page and refer to the “Customize Payment Terms” section.

title: Why was application refused? (Refused due to FI restrictions)
content:
Your application was refused because of a restriction on one of your loans with a Financial Institution. 
 
For more details on the restriction, please contact your financial institution.

title: Why was my application refused? (Stale Dated)
content:
Your paper Repayment Assistance Plan (RAP) application was refused because it was stale dated. This means that your application was received 40 days or more after the application was signed and you need to re-apply. 
 
Please submit a new application online. Click on the "My Account" and select “Repayment Assistance Plan” from the drop-down menu. Scroll down to the bottom of the page and click “Apply On-Line Now”. Your application will be processed within 3 business days.
 
If you are approved for RAP, you can view the details of your RAP period including the start and end date through the Loan Details page. If we need more information to process your application, we will send a message to your secure inbox with the details.

title: Why was my loan sent to the government?
content:
Canada Student Loans and Integrated Student Loans are returned to the government for collection if you have missed 9 months of student loan payments.
 
You can bring your loan up to date through loan rehabilitation.(https://www.canada.ca/en/services/benefits/education/student-aid/grants-loans/repay/unable-repay.html)
 
To rehabilitate your loan, you will need to contact the CRA(https://www.canada.ca/en/revenue-agency/corporate/contact-information.html) to make a payment arrangement to bring your loan up to date. For the provincial or territorial part of your student loan, you need to contact your province or territory(https://www.canada.ca/en/services/benefits/education/student-aid/grants-loans/province-apply.html).
 
Visit the In Collections(https://www.csnpe-nslsc.canada.ca/en/stages-of-a-loan) page for more details.

title: Will my tuition be paid?
content:
Your tuition will be paid only if your school has requested any funding to be forwarded to pay your tuition. Otherwise, you will be responsible for paying your own tuition with the funds you receive.
 
For more information, check with your school's student financial assistance office.
